Award.AwardTitle: An integrated geochemical and geodynamical approach to the origin of off-axis melt production at a range of mid-ocean ridge settings
Award.AbstractNarration: Understanding how ocean crust is created and its how melts of different chemistry are created is an essential but presently poorly constrained aspect of global geochemical cycling between the mantle and crust. This research investigates the geochemical relationship between on- and off-axis volcanism at a variety of mid-ocean ridge spreading center settings to try and develop an integrated dynamic geochemical and geophysical modeling approach to better understand the interaction of mantle heterogeneities with the mid-ocean ridge system. A key component of this work will be to examine the geochemistry of four well-studied mid-ocean ridges (East Pacific Rise, Iceland, Galapagos, and the Juan de Fuca Ridge) to predict the degree and depth of melting required to produce off-axis melts and relate these predictions to physically realistic origins in the mantle. To create a more complete geochemical record of off-axis geochemical variation, samples from 20 seamounts near the East Pacific Rise will be analyzed for the radiogenis isotoes of Sr, Nd, and Pb, which are indicators of magmatic and magma differentiation processes. A major reserach goal is to develop robust one and two dimensional models to determine whether or not there are globally consistent off-axis processes that underpin mantle melting beneath mid-ocean ridges. The broader impacts of the work include developing the career of a postdoc from a group under-represented in the sciences and public outreach through a local Florida museum. Broader impacts also include international collaboration with a UK scientist, with the postdoc spending time in the collaborator's laboratory and being cross-trained in state-of the art geochemical analytical techniques and geodynamical modeling.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

The generation of new oceanic crust occurs at mid-ocean ridges where two tectonic plates are spreading apart. Magma supplied to the seafloor originates from melting the mantle beneath the ridge. While the majority of melts are focused to the center of the ridge to form the bulk of the new crust, a significant component may be focused away from the axis to produce off-axis eruptions. There is much debate over the true origin of lavas emplaced off-axis. We set out to resolve that debate with a multi-faceted approach using new geochemical data, high spatial density geochemical datasets and physically realistic forward geochemical models based on two-dimensional numerical models of mantle flow and melting beneath a ridge. We studied multiple ridges and multiple styles of off-axis volcanic construction to gain a broader understanding of the link between lava compositions off-axis and mantle melting beneath the ridge.

One of our most significant finding was that off-axis lava flows at the East Pacific Rise (EPR) and Juan de Fuca Ridge (JdFR) originate from off-axis eruptions and have not just flowed from the central region of the axis. The spatial variation in composition of flows away from the axis suggests that off-axis eruptions progressively resurface the seafloor as new oceanic crust migrates away from the axis. The compositional variation also mirrors the spatial distribution of magma beneath the ridge as determined by seismic observations. We concluded that off-axis volcanism plays a more significant role in the construction of the seafloor than previously thought and provides a present-day geochemical snapshot of the magma supplied to, and stored beneath, the ridge.

Additionally, an integrated geochemical modeling investigation of the Vance near-ridge seamounts at the JdFR revealed that the mantle beneath the ridge is comprised at least two different components. Our modeling indicates that the mantle retains a history of prior melting events that is subsequently recorded by the seamounts. The geochemistry of lava flows sampled from the chain of seamounts up to 70km off-axis varies systematically with distance from the ridge. We suggest that these variations reflect an evolution in mantle geochemistry as each seamount depleted the local mantle combined with progressive incorporation of fresh mantle from beneath the center of the ridge as the closest seamounts to the ridge formed.

Results from this project were presented to the broader scientific community at AGU meetings in San Francisco in 2012-2014 as well as at multiple institutions around the US and in Australia. Some results were published in a peer-reviewed journal and others are in preparation for publication.

 

Broader Impacts

We constructed two high spatial density geochemical datasets that extend up to 5km from the axis – one for the 9-10°N segment of the EPR and one for the Cleft segment of the JdFR. At the EPR we compiled 20+ years worth of published and unpublished geochemical analyses totaling over 1800 individual geochemical analyses. This database was submitted to the EarthChem libraries, which is a freely accessible online geochemical data repository.

As part of the project’s commitment to public outreach, PI Walters built an augmented reality sandbox that provides a magical experience introducing surface water dynamics to users. The sandbox has visited two schools, including a whole day with a special needs class, and the annual department outreach event –“Can You Dig It?”– that attracts up to 2000 visitors each year. Walters has also provided advice and support to several schools and institutions around the country to construct their own version. The augmented reality sandbox will continue to be a favorite at the annual department outreach event for many years to come.

In addition to “Can You Dig It?”, Walters and Co-PI Perfit have participated in multiple public out reach events including “WiSE Girlz” – a spring science camp for local high school girls, “She’s a Scientist” – outreach event at the local museum for girl scouts and “Talk Science to Me” – an event where scientists are placed in local establishments where the general public we encouraged to chat with scientists about their research.

Throughout the time of this project Walters has provided significant mentoring and training, formally and informally, for numerous graduate students. Walters was instrumental in creating a careers development program conducted annually to educate graduate and undergraduate students about the variety of career options for Earth scientists outside of academia.

Finally, one of the major broader impact goals of this project was the professional development of a young female scientist (Walters) under the mentorship of Perfit. Walters gained invaluable training and experience in many aspects of research during the course of this project. Walters continues to participate in research, but has now redirected her knowledge and experience toward developing innovative teaching methods for the geosciences using a team-based learning environment.
